Comments_List: I learned how to actually plan helpful interventions and what paths to follow to carry them out. Besides the interesting readings and discussions, this course was very project based, and that was really useful.
I learned what I already knew, about implicit bias and discrimination and isolation in STEM, but it was nice to have a platform to talk about these things.
I learned about how identity intersects with STEM fields.
I feel more comfortable with taking to my profs.

This course is still relatively new, so I think more years of teaching could refine it. The turnover of new professors is also a problem of continuity, the course will change drastically based on that.
I think the course should have fewer lectures (although it already does not have many) and be almost entirely discussion and project based.
very good but need to be more organized

There should be more representation among the professors. If not, they should approach the class from more of a listening and learning perspective. I didnt learn much in the class, but we began to have some important conversations about race, gender, sexuality, ability, and socioeconomic status.
Yes. Very cool, especially if you're interested in education and diversity in STEM.
Yes, for sure, if one is into STEM and advocating for humans in it!

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. It was very refreshing to be able to talk about diversity and identity in a STEM environment. I learned a lot and felt I was also able to teach others and make a tangible change on the campus with the project.
